DataElement.preferredName: Pathology Specimen Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Cell Count Category
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Classification of a pathology specimen based on hematoxylin and eosin (H+E) staining for cell count.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Pathology Specimen Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Slide Submitted
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: related to pieces of glass on which tissue samples are mounted, after preparation with a routine two-stain process, that are referred to specialists who identify cellular change caused by disease.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A specialty concerned with the nature and cause of disease as expressed by changes in cellular or tissue structure and function caused by the disease process. (MSH98):Specimen; a bit of tissue or blood or urine that is taken or used for research purposes.

Concepts.definition: The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

A part of a thing, or of several things, taken to demonstrate or to determine the character of the whole, e.g. a substance, or portion of material obtained for use in testing, examination, or study; particularly, a preparation of tissue or bodily fluid taken for examination or diagnosis.

Property.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Slide Submitted
Property.preferredDefinition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.:A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.:Submitted; referred for judgment or consideration.

Concepts.definition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.
A flat rectangular piece of glass on which specimens can be mounted for microscopic study.
The act of referring for judgment or consideration by others; the act of handing over something.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: attributes of a patient's laboratory sample, including the source, condition, and fixative.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Cell Count Category
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen._A procedure to determine the number of cells in a sample. Also used to mean the result of such a procedure._Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

RepresentationTerm.preferredName: Hematoxylin and Eosin Staining Method Cell Count Category
RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.:A procedure to determine the number of cells in a sample. Also used to mean the result of such a procedure.:Category; used informally to mean a class of things.

Concepts.definition: Hematoxylin-and-eosin, or H&E, is a routine staining procedure of tissue sections. This staining method uses two separate dyes, one staining the nucleus and the other staining the cytoplasm and connective tissue. Hematoxylin is a dark purplish dye that stains the chromatin (nuclear material) within the nucleus. Eosin is an orangish-pink to red dye that stains the cytoplasmic material including connective tissue and collagen.
A procedure to determine the number of cells in a sample.
A grouping of items based on some commonality or by user defined characteristics.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support Lombardi Cancer Center adoption of C3D
